TEXT.TEXTVALUE: Click on each apparatus/reagent to know its name or click on the "Continue" to start the experiment.
A beaker is placed on the lab bench.
The pH electrode is removed from the electrode storage solution.
The bottle containing distilled water is taken from the lab bench.
The pH electrode is then thoroughly washed with distilled water.
The bottle is then returned to the lab bench.
The CAL button is pressed.
The pH electrode is then dipped inside the bottle labeled “pH=4”.
When “Ready” is displayed on the pH meter, the Enter button is pressed.
The pH electrode is then taken from the bottle labeled “pH=4”.
The bottle containing distilled water is taken from the lab bench.
The pH electrode is then thoroughly washed with distilled water.
The bottle is then returned to the lab bench.
A lint free tissue paper is taken from the box.
The bulb of the pH electrode is wiped gently using the tissue paper.
The pH electrode is then dipped inside the bottle labeled “pH=7”.
When “Ready” is displayed on the pH meter, the Enter button is pressed.
The pH electrode is then taken from the bottle labeled “pH=7”.
The bottle containing distilled water is taken from the lab bench.
The pH electrode is then thoroughly washed with distilled water.
The bottle is then returned to the lab bench.
A lint free tissue paper is taken from the box.
The bulb of the pH electrode is wiped gently using the tissue paper.
The pH electrode is then dipped inside the bottle labeled “pH=10”.
When “Ready” is displayed on the pH meter, the Enter button is pressed.
The pH electrode is then taken from the bottle labeled “pH=10”.
The bottle containing distilled water is taken from the lab bench.
The pH electrode is then thoroughly washed with distilled water.
The bottle is then returned to the lab bench.
The pH electrode is then placed onto the pH electrode stand.
A glass pipette is inserted into the pipette pump.
20 ml of the 0.1M glycine is pipetted out using glass pipette. The lid of the standard flask is then replaced.
20 ml of glycine is pipetted using a pipette.
The pipetted solution is then transferred to a beaker and is removed from the lab bench.
The beaker containing glycine is then placed on the stirrer and the pH electrode is dipped inside it.
The magnetic stir bar is taken from the lab bench using forceps.
The stir bar is then transferred to the beaker containing 0.1M glycine and the stirrer is switched on.
The pH is recorded.
The stopcock of the burette is released.
0.3ml of HCl is added dropwise from the burette into the beaker containing 0.1M glycine.
The stop cock of the burette is then closed.
The pH observed is recorded.
The stopcock of the burette is released.
Another 0.3 ml of the HCl is added dropwise from the burette into the beaker containing 0.1M glycine.
The stop cock of the burette is then closed.
The pH observed is recorded.
The stopcock of the burette is released.
Another 0.3 ml of the HCl is added drop wise from the burette into the beaker containing 0.1M glycine.
The stop cock of the burette is then closed.
The pH observed is recorded.
Similarly repeat the same procedure until the pH reaches 1.6. The pH values are recorded in a tabular column.
The magnetic stirrer is switched off.
The pH electrode is then taken from the beaker containing 0.1M glycine and the beaker is then removed from the stirrer. The pH electrode is then fixed back to the stand.
The beaker is then returned to the lab bench.
The pH electrode is then taken from the stand.
The bottle containing distilled water is taken from the lab bench.
The pH electrode is then thoroughly washed with distilled water.
The bottle is then returned to the lab bench.
The pH electrode is then placed onto the pH electrode stand.
The burette stand with the burette containing HCl is taken from the lab bench.
Another burette containing NaOH is taken from the lab table.
Then the burette is placed through the slot of the pH meter.
A glass pipette is inserted into the pipette pump.
20 ml of the 0.1M glycine is pipetted out using glass pipette. The lid of the standard flask is then replaced.
20 ml of the 0.1M glycine is pipetted out.
The pipetted solution is then transferred to a beaker and it is taken from the lab bench.
The beaker containing glycine is then placed on the stirrer and the pH electrode is dipped inside it.
The magnetic stir bar is taken from the lab bench using forceps.
The stir bar is then transferred to the beaker containing 0.1M glycine and the stirrer is switched on.
The pH is recorded.
The stopcock of the burette is released.
0.3ml of NaOH is added dropwise from the burette into the beaker containing 0.1M glycine.
The stop cock of the burette is then closed.
The pH observed is recorded.
The stopcock of the burette is released.
Another 0.3 ml of the NaOH is added dropwise from the burette into the beaker containing 0.1M glycine.
The stop cock of the burette is then closed.
The pH observed is recorded.
The stopcock of the burette is released.
Another 0.3 ml of the NaOH is added dropwise from the burette into the beaker containing 0.1M glycine.
The stop cock of the burette is then closed.
The pH observed is recorded.
Similarly repeat the same procedure until the pH reaches 12.00. The pH values are recorded in a tabular column.
notext
A titration curve is plotted with Volume of HCl in ml on X axis and pH on Y axis.
Another titration curve is plotted with Volume of NaOH in ml on X axis and pH on Y axis.
